In Zimbabwe, Evan Mawarire created what's become a popular opposition movement called hashtag #ThisFlag with a simple online video.
Over the past several months, the Baptist pastor has been arrested and threatened for criticizing President Robert Mugabe's government and encouraging demonstrations against corruption there.
Now he's visiting the United States for a time, but some of his supporters say he's abandoned his cause at a critical moment.
Pastor Mawarire stopped by our NPR studios late last week.
I asked him to explain why his movement seems to be resonating in his country.
I think it has grown very naturally in terms of people wanting a platform where they can really genuinely express how they feel let down by their own country.
Over the last 20 years, it has become obvious that Robert Mugabe and the ruling party, ZANU-PF, are not really interested in letting anyone else build Zimbabwe.

And the many people that have watched the videos or that have become part of the movement have all said to me, you know, part of what we've been dealing with is this love that we have for Zimbabwe and the hate we have for what has happened to her, and trying to bridge that gap and trying to come back to a place where I say, she's mine.
I am her and she is me.
And even though she's ravaged, I love her deeply.
I want to go back to April, to the very beginning of the This Flag movement, when you first recorded this video.

It was the last thing on my mind.
